comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: They look like McDonald Truss bridges.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Yes! The foreground bridge is the Berowa Creek Bridge over Galston Gorge. McDonald timber truss road bridge built in 1892 and replaced in 1937. See - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=194816 The smaller bridge in the distance still exists today - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/leorex/72743535/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thank you for your contribution pellethepoet, our records have been updated. What a remarkable piece of information, especially in light of the fact that the Roads and Maritime Services determined that it was of great historical significance to the State.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  GORGE-ous !  

What a fabulous collection of Hawkesbury River and tributaries photos this is.  I love all the damage, crinkles and creases too.  Patina!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Newly built bridges: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=991197&am... [Pay no attention to the c.1871 date - it's a loose photo slipped into a c.1871 album.] Note the winch. For what purpose? Still there in this photo.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Fantastic photograph thanks for sharing! Hmm, the [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/] pic appears to be taken a little earlier based on the fence in the foreground, near the winch. Not really sure what the winch was used for. Did you all see this heritage report from the Roads & Maritime Services?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: No idea what the winch was for, but the fence looks odd - blocking access to the new bridge, suggesting this photo is before the bridge opened. The road is looking new too. So this c.1892 date might provide a clue to the other Hawkesbury photos. GooglMapsStreetView of the smaller bridge a road sign calls it "Tunks Creek, Galston Bridge 1893". Btw the unusual diagonal deck planking mentioned in the Heritage Report (and still there) we have seen before at the 1893 Cowra Road Bridge - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4752976741/ . Diagonal decks were huge in 1893!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Speaking of identifying bridges, did you check out any of the other photos in the amazing c.1871 album? I've just identified 25, 64, & 216 as the original (1854) laminated arch road bridge at Yass, with reference to this Yass panorama (showing the 1871 bridge): acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63812 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63813 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63814 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63815 Have also id'd 111 as Orange and 44, 46 [School of Arts], 48, 121, & 147 as Bathurst. I'm feeling a little guilty for not including you, but there are plenty more that need sleuthing! :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Which c.1871 album?  So many albums, so little time ...

EDIT - Found it!  Pity we can't scribble all over the photos.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Just had a look through that album - lots of identifiable stuff. Another one of Yass --- No.83 Mechanics Institute with extrordinary kangaroos on the roof ! If you are making a list for the SLNSW .... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Sorry, we seem to have gone off on a tangent ... Second thoughts about that fence - it is not across the bridge, but on the next level up, round the hairpin bend, and the photographer is on another level up still - see the GoogleSatellite image. They were building the fence, and the winch was for hauling the timber up?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I'll be making a list and checking it twice ...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
